content.title: Isolina, Peruvian culinary heritage regained

introduction.small: In the Barranco neighbourhood, an old inn sheds its skin and offers traditional Peruvian recipes that were almost gone.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Isolina, Peruvian culinary heritage regained

paragraphs.text:
Criolla cuisine – traditional and popular Peruvian gastronomy – almost disappeared. That is, until José del Castillo stepped in. The chef and owner wants to pay tribute to the dishes from his childhood and to do so, he set up home in an old inn and bodega built in 1906, now listed as Peruvian historical heritage. Completely and tastefully restored, retaining the exposed beams of the structure, it keeps the past in check but opens up to the future. Make a first stop at the bar on ground floor for homemade cocktails, before climbing up to greater things.

You will taste a cuisine mainly based off sauce and offals, yet modernised for new generations of food lovers. Meat stews, sausages and tacu tacu (rice and broad beans mix) will provide for a change of scenery. Fear not, the menu offers a multitude of more classic dishes that are no less delicious: the ceviche, for instance, is a safe bet.

Isolina
Av San Martin 101
Barranco
Lima 15063

+51 (0)1 247 5075

http://isolina.pe/en/home/

Menu: from 60 PEN

content.title: El Pan De La Chola, trendy bakery

introduction.small: With a first shop successfully opened in Miraflores, El Pan De La Chola takes over another neighbourhood in Lima.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Pan De La Chola, trendy bakery

paragraphs.text:
In a semi-industrial setting where wood and steel come together, the smell of bakery fills up the vast and bright space. People sitting at the tables order sandwiches, salads, pizzas and obviously bread, always served warm and crispy. There, raw ingredients are brought out for simple yet quite effective results: fig pastries, or an appetising fried egg served with cherry tomatoes and crispy potatoes, you will rediscover the genuine taste of food. From your chair, a delicious Peruvian café latte served in front of you, you can observe bakers working in the open-plan kitchen, next to the huge wood-fired oven covered in red tiles. Indulge in pastries, cakes, cookies, brownies, almond and chocolate croissants, spread around the counter. Best enjoyed to stay or to take away and devour by the sea, for a resolutely savoury breakfast!

El Pan De La Chola
Calle Miguel Dasso 113-115
San Isidro
Lima 15073

+51 (0)1 22 12 138

www.facebook.com/elpandelachola/

Menu: pastries from 6 PEN

content.title: Cosme, ecofriendly gastronomy

introduction.small: Sustainable development and ecology are paramount at Cosme in Lima, a restaurant that offers Peruvian cuisine with a contemporary twist.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cosme, ecofriendly gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
Only a few steps from the seafront, in Lima's San Isidro district, Cosme has taken up the trail of sustainable development. Inside the restaurant, a very stripped-down decor, with white walls and wooden furniture, showcases some 4,000 multicoloured plastic bottles attached to the ceiling. About 13,000 stoppers add some colour to the back wall with, at their centre, the restaurant's logo: it depicts a harrier bird, which, according to chef James Berckemeyer, is an animal that makes recycling within its ecosystem possible.
At the stove, and abiding by the principle he cares for, he only uses local and seasonal products to prepare heartwarming dishes, based on the codes of Peruvian gastronomy. On the menu, Cosme-styled rice (with pork, peppers, yellow French beans, eggs and fried banana) and quinoa croquetas (with grand Padano, bacon and Cajun sauce) are only some of the inspired examples of this traditional cuisine. A modern take on food, with gourmet, flawless and responsible execution.

Cosme
Tudela y Varela 162
San Isidro
Lima

+51 (0)1 42 15 228

www.cosme.com.pe/cosme/ ﻿

Menu: around 70 PEN

content.title: La Picantería, the taste of sharing

introduction.small: Once forgotten, picanterías are reappearing in the streets of Lima. An opportunity to rediscover the true flavours of traditional Peruvian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Picantería, the taste of sharing

paragraphs.text:
In 19th-century Peru, picanterías were neighbourhood restaurants where workers met up at lunchtime. Today, in the Surquillo de Lima district, chef Héctor Solís brings the tradition up to date with his restaurant La Picantería. The turquoise blue walls, wooden bar and two long tables covered in vinyl tablecloths encourage passing tourists to sit down side-by-side with locals.

The blackboard may have fish or seafood that you can try, depending on the catch of the day. On the menu today, sardines, crayfish and lobster. If you happen to prefer meat, opt for the duck ceviche, or the causa rellena, a traditional Peruvian dish with chicken, avocado and potatoes. Accompany your meal with a glass of chicha de jora, a typically Peruvian drink similar to beer.

La Picantería
Francisco Moreno 388
Esquina Con Cuadra 6 de Gonzales Prada
Surquillo
Lima 15047

+51 (0)1 241 6676

www.picanteriasdelperu.com

Menu: around 83 PEN

content.title: Pachacamac: an ancient citadel

introduction.small: Far from the major streets of the city, certain places offer an opportunity to connect with the popular soul of Peru.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pachacamac: an ancient citadel

paragraphs.text:
Some 30 km from the city centre, Pachacamac is one of the 43 districts of Lima. It is best known for its archaeological site, which, upon the arrival of the Spanish conquistadors, was an Inca city of the first order.

You can visit, in a deserted neighbourhood, a succession of palaces and pyramid temples of adobe and stone, damaged by time. Excavations have uncovered monumental staircases. Those of the sun temple are impressive, and you can climb them to the top of the building. Although a 2007 earthquake has diminished the site, the Palacio de la Mamacuna has preserved a remarkable sculpted trapezoidal door in the Incan style.

On the way back to the small village of Pachacamac, take a moment at the charming Pisco Museum, before climbing a hill to the ‘Piedra del Amor' (Stone of Love) to make a wish.

Citadel of Pachacamac
Autopista Antigua Panamericana
Pachacamac
Lima 15823

+51 (0)1 430 0168

content.title: Quinta Miraflores: a charming stopover

introduction.small: Built in the early 20th century, this colonial-style building is permanently festooned with the beautiful blooms of exotic flowers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quinta Miraflores: a charming stopover

paragraphs.text:
The presence of a Starbucks coffee shop does not alter this deliciously romantic setting, especially as the Quinta Miraflores offers the exquisite feeling of being invited into a private home. Charm and authenticity play together in this warmly decorated establishment with hardwood floors, beautiful fabrics, and elegant furnishings.

Though without an elevator, a slight inconvenience for luggage, you will enjoy the intimate and charming character of the four rooms, personalised with taste and featuring a mini bar. Breakfast is served in your room until late, a serious advantage for night owls and those who love to sleep in. The service is discreet and attentive. Taxis are always at the door.

The perfect place to explore the festive Miraflores district and the buzzing seaside, which abounds with true marvels unaffected by time. Not to mention a host of typical and very inviting small bars.

Quinta Miraflores
28 de Julio 844
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 446 5147

www.quintamiraflores.com

Rooms: from 402 PEN

content.title: Museo Pedro de Osma: a confidential address in Barranco

introduction.small: Don Pedro de Osma Gildemeister, a noble philanthropist and non-conformist, once lived in this elegant Baroque-style castle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museo Pedro de Osma: a confidential address in Barranco

paragraphs.text:
Building this house in Barranco in 1906, at the time a decrepit village without any history, demonstrated the pioneering personality of Don Pedro de Osma Gildemeister. As did his filling it with a remarkable collection of colonial art.

Once a week, Don Pedro agreed to receive foreigners to expound on his passions and treasures. When he died, his heirs, through a foundation, followed in his footsteps, expanding the collection and keeping it open to the public: the love of art cannot survive if it is not shared. A national monument since 1987, it is now a full-fledged museum.

Among its key pieces are paintings from the Cusco School and the School of the Spanish Golden Age, including Flight into Egypt by Zurbaranesca, an Inquisition-era inkwell, and a Madonna by Mendoza. There is a small cafeteria in the garden.

Museo Pedro de Osma
Pedro de Osma Avenue 421
Barranco
Lima 15063

+51 (0)1 467 0141

http://museopedrodeosma.org/en/

content.title: The Magic Water Tour of the Park of the Reserve

introduction.small: Framed by two very busy streets, the Paseo de la Republica Expressway and Avenida Arequipa, is the green, eight-hectare oasis of the Peruvian capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Magic Water Tour of the Park of the Reserve

paragraphs.text:
Right in the city centre, this pleasant park allows you to fill your lungs with fresh air while admiring sculptures by Peruvian artists and the neoclassical buildings of French architect Claude Sahut.

What draws a million annual visitors, however, is the sensational Magic Water Tour (El Circuito Mágico del Agua), registered in the Guinness Book of Records for the sophisticated complexity of its water games, music, and lights. People come here to splash in the water all day, and to take in the great night show, orchestrated around a dozen beautifully illuminated fountains. The most impressive attractions are the Magic Fountain, which shoots a jet of water up to 80 metres in the air, and the Fantasia Fountain, which projects lasers onto a liquid wall.

You'll be amazed by the modernity of this incredible interactive world, which involves a profusion of synchronised jets, with a coordinated soundtrack combining Peruvian waltzes and Abba's greatest hits.

Parque de la Reserva
Madre de Dios
Lima 15046

+51 (0)1 331 0353

www.circuitomagicodelagua.com.pe/ing/index.php

content.title: MATE: a cultural centre started by Mario Testino

introduction.small: A native of Lima, multi-talented photographer Mario Testino has always fascinated the glamourous scene.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MATE: a cultural centre started by Mario Testino

paragraphs.text:
Famous all over the world for his joint efforts with the high priestess of porno chic Carine Roitfeld, Peruvian fashion photographer Mario Testino often makes the headlines with his Vogue covers and celebrity portraits, including some for Madonna and Kate Moss. The innovative photographer has opened a museum and foundation in the gallery and antique district of Barranco. Many of the large format photographs on the walls promote the art and culture of Peru. The MATE program also includes an ambitious lecture series and a dynamic program centred on painting and photography. Emerging and established artists—Vik Muniz, Julian Schnabel, and Cindy Sherman, to name just three—have been among the invited guests.

MATE Museo Mario Testino
Pedro de Osma 409
Barranco
Lima 15063

+51 (0)1 251 7755

www.mate.pe

content.title: The Inca Trail: the adventure of a lifetime

introduction.small: Lost citadels, valleys shrouded in mist. The most famous trek in South America more than delivers on its promise.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Inca Trail: the adventure of a lifetime

paragraphs.text:
Hiking this secret path, unknown to the Conquistadors, is an unforgettable experience, an initiation rite that shakes soul and body.

Each year, thousands of travellers engage in this four-day, 43-km hike, which requires an average fitness level but a real adaptation to the altitude. Between tropical forests and snowy peaks, a sequence of remarkable sites is reached: not only ‘the city on top of the terraces' and the ‘hummingbird', but also waterfalls and hidden ruins balanced precariously on steep cliffs.

Three passes, the last at 3,600 metres, take you to an Inca tunnel cut into the rock, which opens onto the Urubamba (Sacred) Valley. The last day is the climb down to Inti Punku. At dawn, the legendary Machu Picchu finally enters the light. Your return to civilisation will require at least two hours of walking.

content.title: Machu Picchu: one of Seven New Wonders of the World

introduction.small: A stone treasure in the Amazon jungle, the most visited site in Peru is this ancient Inca city of the 15th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Machu Picchu: one of Seven New Wonders of the World

paragraphs.text:
From Cusco, you can reach this fabulous lost city, overlooking the eastern slopes of the Central Andes, by train or the Inca Trail. Abandoned at the collapse of the Inca empire, the Sacred City, forgotten for centuries, is a sanctuary and an archaeological site of the highest order.

At its peak, Machu Picchu was probably the most amazing urban creation of the modern New World. The site was divided into two distinct areas. The agricultural zone is recognisable by its characteristic terraces, suitable for crops and endowed with an ingenious rainwater drainage system.

The urban area was organised around a main square, which housed the people, the residence of the Emperor, the sacrificial altars, and the famous Sun Temple. Stairways offered access to areas reserved for the nobility, priests, and merchants.

Machu Picchu
Cusco
Peru

+51 (0)1 574 8000

www.machupicchu.gob.pe

content.title: JW Marriott Hotel: a masterpiece of contemporary luxury

introduction.small: This vertiginous glass tower is the work of the architecture firm Arquitectonica, whose Torre Begonias is the tallest building in Peru.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: JW Marriott Hotel: a masterpiece of contemporary luxury

paragraphs.text:
It is only natural that JW Marriott, a leader in international luxury, should operate one of the greatest hotels on the South American continent. Located in the heart of Miraflores and bordering the Pacific Ocean, its prime location is the best starting point to explore Lima and its cultural riches, or for a morning jog along the beach.

Some rooms and suites have glass walls with spectacular views of the sky and the bay. All are characterised by a refined elegance of extreme comfort and the highest standard of services. Service is flawless: everything is perfectly orchestrated for an idyllic and exclusive sojourn. The perfect ending point for adventurers returning from the Nazca desert, or the just-arrived still under the effects of jet lag.

JW Marriott Hotel
Malecón de la Reserva 615
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 217 7000

www.marriott.com

Rooms: from 895 PEN

content.title: Mercado Dédalo, for bohemian arts and crafts

introduction.small: In the effervescent Barranco district, this incredible gallery has become all the rage.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mercado Dédalo, for bohemian arts and crafts

paragraphs.text:
All the cool-looking bric-a-brac imaginable adorns the nooks and crannies of this bargain-hunting paradise, a concept store where you can buy everything from original Peruvian quinoa to alpaca sweaters, local crafts, and decorative items designed by young contemporary artists. There is lots of ready-to-wear by Peruvian designers, along with jewellery, tableware, ceramics, handbags, and luggage. The beautiful books in the library, ranging from tomes on Peruvian magic to children's lit, can be signed out or read on the premises. There is a bar at the back, with tables under the trees in the garden. Don't miss the annex, Dédalo Arte y Artesanía, which has a very astutely curated selection, dedicated to the artistic avant-garde of the last two decades.

Mercado Dédalo
Saenz Peña 295
Barranco
Lima 15063

+51 (0)1 477 5131

https://www.dedalo.pe

content.title: Carnaval Ayacuchano de Lima: a traditional celebration

introduction.small: If you are visiting Lima in late March, don't miss the unforgettable Ayacuchano carnival.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Carnaval Ayacuchano de Lima: a traditional celebration

paragraphs.text:
Ayacucho, a city and a province in southern Peru, attracts crowds with its complex folklore, acrobatic dances, and living traditions.

Every year the carnival is an opportunity to unite all the villages of the region. It takes place mainly in the Santa Rosa complex, between the centre of Lima and Rimac, one of the poorest districts of the city. Tourists are rare for this unique event; it's best to be guided by locals.

It's a fabulous party in a very friendly neighbourhood. At night, the arena turns into a dance floor. You might not be able to master the Andean dances, which can be tricky, but the catchy, often melancholic melodies are sure to grab you.

Santa Rosa District
On the main road to the banking centre of Santa Anita
Ayacucho

Lima 15064

www.deperu.com/abc/carnavales-peruanos/2808/carnaval-de-ayacucho

content.title: Museo Larco: the fascinating civilisations of the New World

introduction.small: One of the most magnificent national ceramic collections is exhibited in this former royal residence of the 18th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museo Larco: the fascinating civilisations of the New World

paragraphs.text:
The Museo Larco, one of the leading museums of Lima, was founded in 1926 by Rafael Larco Hoyle, a Peruvian archaeologist and avid collector of pre-Columbian sculptures. It has many original pieces. More than 50,000 vases are listed and thousands of objects can be seen under glass.

An exceptional collection of Moche ceramics from the first century to the eighth demonstrates the creative diversity of this little-known culture. The exhibition is a visual encyclopaedia unmatched in the Americas.

Equally fascinating are the richly embroidered textiles and ceramics, and the remarkable masks, jewellery, and works in precious metals, which span more than 4,000 years of history and many cultures, including Cupisnique, Lambayeque, Virú, Chimú, and Inca. Admission is free.

Museo Larco
Av. Simón Bolivar 1515
Pueblo Libre
Lima 15084

+51 (0)1 461 1312

www.museolarco.org

content.title: Nanka: outstanding cuisine

introduction.small: In the district of La Molina, away from the city centre, Nanka is one of the authentic hearts of Peruvian gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nanka: outstanding cuisine

paragraphs.text:
The welcome and service at this beautiful spot behind a wall of bamboo are provided by young professionals, passionate and proud of their country, and ready to answer all your questions.

Developed around an experimental design, the menu encourages the idea of sharing dishes and specialties among guests. Among the many suggestions is a seasonal menu offering an ingenious overall view of the specialties. Nanka, like many of the addresses in Lima, prides itself on only using local products of the highest quality, usually organic.

Special mention goes to the artichoke ravioli, Vietnamese spring rolls with spicy sauce, and Nanka duck ceviche, staples of South American cuisine.

Nanka La Molina
Jr. Bambúes198 (at the back of CC Molina Plaza)
La Molina
Lima 15024
+51 (0)1 369 7297
https://www.nanka.pe
Menu: around 96 PEN

Nanka San Isidro
Calle Manuel Bañón 260
San Isidro
Lima 15073
+51 (0)1 467 8417
https://www.nanka.pe
Menu: around 96 PEN

content.title: Dazzler Lima: an exclusive address

introduction.small: Opened in 2013, this modern building is home to the best designer hotel in the capital, just a few steps from the Brazilian Embassy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dazzler Lima: an exclusive address

paragraphs.text:
The Dazzler is a jewel of contemporary aesthetics, designed by a famous interior designer. The 140 rooms are huge, done up with minimalist elegance and emphasising serenity. Purists will enjoy the contemporary furniture cohabiting with the beautiful lights and the latest high-tech innovations.

Frequented in the late afternoon by the world of fashion and art, the outdoor pool in varnished teak promises relaxation and freshness. There is a gorgeous roof terrace, high above the urban din with dreamy views of the horizon. The area is central, one block from a small neighbourhood supermarket.

Don't overlook the Parque Kennedy, beloved by Lima residents. The nearby streets of Santa Cruz and des Conquistadors are well stocked with designer clothes and watch boutiques.

Dazzler Hotel
Av. José Pardo 879
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 634 4000

https://www.wyndhamhotels.com/dazzler

Rooms: from 449 PEN

content.title: Lima San Isidro by Pullman: a business hotel deserving your full attention

introduction.small: This modernist achievement combines glass, wood, and concrete to create spaces that are open, airy, and bright.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lima San Isidro by Pullman: a business hotel deserving your full attention

paragraphs.text:
This property is conveniently located in a residential area, away from the turmoil of the city. It provides customers with a full shuttle service, very convenient for exploring the city at any time of day or night. Anyway, a couple of minutes is all it takes for you to reach the bustling streets of San Isidro, known for its nightlife, colourful fauna, and a multitude of bars and shops. Rooms are incredibly spacious, with beautiful living areas and panoramic views of the city. They are also equipped with all the modern amenities, including Wi-Fi and satellite channels. The bar serves an excellent pisco sour, and the fine dining restaurant has an international menu. There's also a great gym and swimming pool. Nothing has been overlooked to ensure your stay is enjoyable.

Lima San Isidro by Pullman
Av. Jorge Basadre 595
San Isidro
Lima 15073

+51 (0)1 208 1200

https://www.accorhotels.com/gb/hotel-B462-pullman-lima-san-isidro-ex-atton/index.shtml

Rooms: from 562 PEN

content.title: La Locanda: in the upmarket embassy district

introduction.small: The restaurant of the Swiss Hotel is very discreet. However, people come from all over the country to dine at this 5-star home of gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Locanda: in the upmarket embassy district

paragraphs.text:
This is a must, among the top five restaurants in Lima, in a classic setting, with pleasant views over the gardens. Ideal for a romantic tête-à-tête as well as for a business dinner, La Locanda has a very loyal, cosmopolitan clientele.

Preceded by an aura of excellence, the menu combines a subtle fusion of Mediterranean and Peruvian flavours. Trust the maître d', an outstanding professional and great advisor who will direct you to an idyllic meal, taking into account your preferences. Several tasting menus are offered, including a breath-taking five-course recitation of the chef's creations.

Here, in supreme elegance, you will be asked if you want to test a sample of the dishes before ordering, preceded by a Maracuya pisco sour, the star cocktail of Peru. The stellar dishes include grilled octopus, feather-light carpaccio, and a scallop tiradito.

La Locanda
Vía Central 150
Av. Sto. Toribio 173
San Isidro
Lima 27

+51 (0)1 421 4400

lalocanda.pe

Menu: around 120 PEN

content.title: MAC, the Contemporary Art Museum, unveils an ambitious agenda

introduction.small: Lima's contemporary art scene is among the most dynamic in South America, the equal of Buenos Aires, Santiago, and Sao Paulo.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MAC, the Contemporary Art Museum, unveils an ambitious agenda

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 2013, MAC is the only museum in Lima that specialises in the dissemination of modern and contemporary art. A private, non-profit organisation, it is principally dedicated to the promotion of visual art.

The philosophical focus is on artistic happenings. Designed by architect Frederick Cooper Llosa, the revolutionary structure is based on the idea of 'island-universes', large green spaces and terrace gardens bordering a pond. A true creative platform, MAC encourages exchanges. Its modern programming involves the different currents occupying the forefront of today's artistic scene.

Dance performances, conferences, and temporary exhibitions showcase recognised talents and local artists strongly anchored in Lima's cultural landscape, such as Alberto Casari.

MAC
Av. Almte. Miguel Grau 1511
Barranco
Lima 15063

+51 (0)1 514 6800

www.maclima.pe

content.title: Casa Moreyra, a flagship restaurant in the capital

introduction.small: ‘Astrid y Gaston' is the signature of an inventive couple who reign supreme in Andean gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Moreyra, a flagship restaurant in the capital

paragraphs.text:
Set in a chic and colourful loft near the Radisson Hotel, this restaurant with private rooms honours traditions, revisited here with a certain audacity.

In the kitchen: the charismatic Gaston Acurio. Named Peruvian chef of the year by the media, he also hosts his own cooking programs, broadcast on Star TV. A world ambassador of Peruvian cuisine, the restaurant of 'Astrid and Gaston' is found repeatedly listed among the best restaurants in the Americas. It is the dean of the novoandina cuisine, this very new trend that puts a contemporary spin on traditional dishes. The menu is seasonal, and always a feast for the taste buds and eyes.

Among the wondrous dishes: seabass with wheat seeds, yellow garlic and creamy green peas. The tasting menu, 29 dishes in all, is a magical journey through the flavours of Peru.

Astrid y Gaston - Casa Moreyra
Av. Paz Soldán 290
San Isidro
Lima 15073
Peru

+51 (0)1 442 2775

www.astridygaston.com

Menu: around 150 PEN
Tasting menu: around 445 PEN

content.title: Maido: delicious fusion of Japanese and Peruvian cuisine

introduction.small: The minimalist decor of Maido is indicative of the rigorous temperament of Mitsuharu Tsumura, the most Peruvian of Japanese chefs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maido: delicious fusion of Japanese and Peruvian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Before setting up shop in this upscale neighbourhood, Tsumara, symbol of Nikkei success and the son of a Japanese emigrant, earned a culinary diploma at an American university, before taking classes in Tokyo.

There he learned the subtleties of Japanese cuisine, among the most regimented in the world. Back in Lima, he opened Maido, which firmly held the course on authenticity, and became an immediate success. Colourful, rich in flavour, and deliciously sophisticated, the menu is a remarkable symphony that highlights sushi, local seafood, and grilled octopus. Among the delicious pairings are tofu and tomatoes marinated in mirin, monkfish and Creole salad, and also grilled pigeon crispy sushi. The intrepid try the syrupy sweetness of a Qollqe Pisco malt as accompaniment.

Maido
Calle San Martin 399 (corner of Calle Colón)
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 446 2512

http://www.maido.pe/en/index.php

Menu: around 390 PEN

content.title: Lake Titicaca: between heaven and earth

introduction.small: You have to go to the small town of Puno, via Arequipa, to reach the largest lake in South America, which borders on Bolivia and Peru.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lake Titicaca: between heaven and earth

paragraphs.text:
A promising tourist site for its outstanding landscape, Puno, folklore capital of Peru, is primarily a port of departure for excursions on Lake Titicaca. Some of the lake's 41 islands are inhabited.

Half an hour by boat takes you to Uros, the largest of the floating islands. Entirely man-made out of bulrushes, which is also a staple of the local diet, the plant is used to make everything from boats to toothbrushes. The people here have kept their traditions and dialects intact. Accompanied by a guide, immerse yourself in the distant past, welcomed by singing women in traditional costumes, who weave their gorgeous fabrics the same way as their ancestors did.

Sometimes a clan leader will show visitors the codes of survival in this strange, secret-laden world.

content.title: El Cordano: a unique address in downtown Lima

introduction.small: This institution from another era is one of the oldest breweries in Lima. It opened in 1905, close to the presidential palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Cordano: a unique address in downtown Lima

paragraphs.text:
Near what was once the central station, this historic house has preserved its original bar, tiles, and ancient woodwork.

Little has changed in the three large rooms, one of which was formerly reserved for women and children. Since opening a century ago, servers officiate in strict uniform and bow tie. Frequented by the high society of Lima and tourists looking for authenticity, it has received every incumbent Peruvian president of the last 100 years (they live just around the corner).

The menu never changes. The delicious Pisco Sour is perfectly paired with calamares salteados, sautéed calamari a la plancha, or the causa limeña , a typical Peruvian salad with potatoes, avocado, tuna or chicken; all dishes being served copiously. The must dish is butifarra, a baguette topped with ham, made before your eyes.

Restaurant Cordano
Jirón Ancash 202
Lima 15001

+51 (0)1 427 0181

www.restaurantcordano.com

Menu: around 70 PEN

content.title: Plaza de Armas: the jewel of the historic centre

introduction.small: This vast area, also called Plaza Mayor and once the heart of the city, was founded by Francisco Pizarro in the 16th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plaza de Armas: the jewel of the historic centre

paragraphs.text:
At the high point of the Spanish Empire, the Plaza de Armas was the strategic centre of Lima. Although no original building has survived, the impressive bronze fountain, which has adorned the centre since 1650, ranks among the most photographed monuments in the city.

Some public buildings are of interest, including the Archbishop's Palace, with its exuberant colonial style and remarkable Moorish-style balcony. To the north east is the Governor's Palace, the residence of the head of state, a majestic Baroque-style building built in 1937. Very popular with visitors, the Changing of the Guard takes place every day at noon.

Soldiers in uniforms conduct disciplined movements, goose-stepping to the rhythm of ‘El Cóndor Pasa' by the Peruvian composer Daniel Alomía Robles. The palace is not open to the public, except for rare exhibits requiring a booking 48 hours in advance.

Plaza de Armas
Jirón de la Unión Cuadra 3
Lima 1

+51 (1) 987 242 236

content.title: Iglesia de Santo Domingo: a place of revered pilgrimage

introduction.small: This church, the burial place of Pizarro, is strongly marked by the darkest period of the Inquisition and its quest for power over the indigenous peoples.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Iglesia de Santo Domingo: a place of revered pilgrimage

paragraphs.text:
In order to build on his land, the conquistador Francisco Pizarro made an alliance with the Peruvian people's most hated man, Vicente Valverde, the Dominican religious instigator of the murder of Atahualpa, the last Inca emperor.

This church, whose plans were revised many times, was completed in the 16th century. A place of worship for locals, it houses the relics of the three major Peruvian saints: San Juan Macias, Santa Rosa de Lima, and San Martin de Porres, the first black saint of the New World. The vast convent, a motionless world of piety and silence, has sculpted facades in the purest Spanish Renaissance style.

Embellished with Baroque paintings and numerous antique tiled mosaics, it aligns a beautiful row of small cloisters, complemented by colonnades and exquisite woodwork. The gentle murmur of fountains evokes dreams and meditation.

Iglesia y convento de Santo Domingo
170 Jirón Camaná
Lima 15001

+51 (0)1 426 5786

www.conventosantodomingo.pe

content.title: Casa Andina Premium Miraflores: two blocks from Parque Kennedy

introduction.small: The Peruvian chain Private Collection has chosen to open it most prestigious address yet in Miraflores.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Andina Premium Miraflores: two blocks from Parque Kennedy

paragraphs.text:
To bring it up to international standards, Private Collection totally revamped this old residential hotel, which, in the 1960s, was Frank Sinatra's favourite haunt during layovers in Lima.

The feel here is very cosy, especially in the elegant 148 rooms and suites that are serene, sleek, monochrome spaces with dark wood beams and panelling. There are many pluses, like beautiful desks in some, or hydromassage bathtubs, astutely arranged for optimised comfort. Casa Andina pampers its residents. They can relax in a beautiful heated pool with waterfalls and water jets, or take advantage of the ultra-modern fitness centre with sauna and massage services.

To the delight of the soul, and as a reminder that culture is inseparable from any stay in the Andean capital of art, magnificent colonial antiques are on display in the halls and corridors.

Casa Andina Premium Miraflores
Av. la Paz 463
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 213 4300

https://www.casa-andina.com/en/destinations/miraflores/hotels/casa-andina-premium-miraflores

Rooms: from 526 PEN

content.title: Second Home Peru: an artist's home

introduction.small: A charming guesthouse with only eight rooms, perched on a hill at the edge of the ocean.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Second Home Peru: an artist's home

paragraphs.text:
The artist-painter Victor Delfin, the Peruvian Dalí, lived in this manor house overlooking the beach. It is now entrusted to his children, yet he is still very active in his workshop, a hidden source of inspiration at the rear of the building.

His work is omnipresent, and the very soul of Peruvian culture inhabits the eight rooms. They are simple, bright, and comfortable, with blond wood furniture and wrought iron beds. Each has its own bathroom. The garden terrace offers panoramic views over the bay of Lima, from the typical small village of Chorrillos to the great Marine Terminal of Callao.

To reach the ocean involves an easy climb down the bajada de banos, a winding lane that leads you directly to the sand. Colourful fishermen's boats dance in the Pacific at your feet; the sea air is crisp and clear, and the azure sky swept by the flight of cormorants.

Second Home Peru Hotel
Domeyer 366 Barranco
Lima 15063

+51 (0)1 247 5522

www.secondhomeperu.com

Rooms: from 410 PEN

content.title: Hotel B: Relais & Châteaux hotel, near Playa las Cascadas

introduction.small: In the early 20th century, Barranco was a favourite vacation spot of the elite of Lima in search of fresh air and quiet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel B: Relais & Châteaux hotel, near Playa las Cascadas

paragraphs.text:
Most of the great bourgeois mansions there have been converted into boutique hotels, as is the case of this beautiful Belle Époque summerhouse, part of the Relais & Châteaux group. Opening onto a delightful flower-filled patio, the 17 rooms, some with baths, are decorated in neutral tones, with much marble and exotic woods. The focus is on luxury codes and elegance of the highest order. On the walls, a rich selection of contemporary Peruvian artists is on display, including a signed José Tola fresco above the bar and large-format Andy Warhol prints, lent by the gallery Lucia La Puente. By late afternoon, the bar and the library are transformed into a salon frequented by the literary and artistic intelligentsia of Lima. Music by Mozart and Boccherini accompany your aperitif—ask the bartender for a pisco sour, among the best in town.

Hotel B
Sáenz Peña 204
Barranco
Lima 15063

+51 (0)1 206 0800

www.hotelb.pe

Rooms: from 732 PEN

content.title: Arequipa: a remarkable colonial city

introduction.small: The second city of Peru brings together the modernity of the capital with the Incan wonders of Cusco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arequipa: a remarkable colonial city

paragraphs.text:
Renowned for its landscapes of dreams, the colonial city of Arequipa has remained true to its origins. In the heart of the city is the Plaza de Armas, a unique example of perfectly preserved Baroque architecture. The buildings lining it are spectacular, with their facades of silar, a local stone of gleaming whiteness.

The highlight is the impressive cathedral, destroyed three times since 1651 by a fire and earthquakes. To the right of the altar, note the unusual presence of a flag of the Vatican, a rare kindness granted by the pope to fewer than 100 religious buildings in the world. The Santa Catalina Monastery, which has occupied an entire city block since 1580, is also worth a visit.

Inside is a maze of cloisters, conducive to contemplation, and gardens of orange trees. Especially noteworthy is the cell of Sister Anna, whose many miracles have marked the history of Arequipa.

Plaza de Armas
Cercado de Lima
Lima 15001

Monasterio de Santa Catalina de Siena
Jirón Andahuaylas 1156
Cercado de Lima
Lima 15001

content.title: Hotel Monasterio: luxury at the foot of the Inca citadels

introduction.small: The most prestigious Cusco hotel offers a magical setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Monasterio: luxury at the foot of the Inca citadels

paragraphs.text:
For an enchanted Interlude in the Sacred Valley, nothing comes close to this architectural masterpiece of the 17th century. A Jesuit monastery for several centuries, it has been converted into a luxury hotel, with 122 rooms and suites in classic chic Spanish colonial style.

Multiple works of art and ancient tapestries adorn the walls, yet modernity is affirmed in every manner, from plasma screen TVs to WiFi, plus bathrooms with marble galore and even a ‘bath butler' available on request. The inner cloister, framed by ancient stone colonnades, is remarkable. It encloses a beautiful exotic garden, shaded by a giant cedar, where breakfast is served, as well as aperitifs and tapas a good place to start before sampling the exquisite menu of El Typay, known for its traditional cuisine and opera concerts.

Hotel Monasterio
Calle Palacio 140
Plazoleta Nazarenas
Cusco

+51 (1) 84 60 4000

www.monasteriohotel.com

Rooms: from 1,735 PEN

content.title: Cathedral of Lima: a major monument

introduction.small: Close to the Archbishop's Palace, this stunning edifice was built in 1535 on a site designated by the crusading evangelist Pizarro.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cathedral of Lima: a major monument

paragraphs.text:
Its remarkable Baroque facade has survived centuries, despite the four major earthquakes that have devastated the city.

That said, it has had to be rebuilt many times: the last major restoration, completed in 1940, totally changed the original appearance of the cathedral, a fate common to many Lima churches under the influence of late 18th-century Neoclassicism. Admire however, along the nave, the work of the different eclectic artists who worked on the decoration of the chapels. Every imaginable style coexists on the altars. Special mention is due Pedro Noguera for his wooden choir, a masterpiece of Rococo exuberance.

At the secluded rear of the building are an ornate sacristy and a religious museum exhibiting paintings and the ceremonial clothing of Catholic worship.

Cathedral of Lima
Jirón Carabaya
Lima 15001

+51 (0)1 427 9647

www.arzobispadodelima.org

content.title: Huaca Pucllana: a pre-Columbian cemetery amid the modern bustle

introduction.small: In a residential area of ​​the capital, this historic site, built between 800 and 1000 AD, stands up to the modern buildings and pollution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Huaca Pucllana: a pre-Columbian cemetery amid the modern bustle

paragraphs.text:
Attributed to the Wari culture, a Middle Horizon civilisation that flourished in the south-central Andes and coastal areas from about 500 to 1000 AD, this recently excavated necropolis is a great boon to the neighbourhood.

Strange to imagine that this place, once dedicated to motorcycle racing, houses so many treasures, including a massive pyramid, which survived because its adobe bricks, positioned vertically, enabled the building to withstand severe earthquakes. In 2013, research by the Huaca Pucllana, funded by the municipality of Miraflores, brought about a breakthrough in the study of this unknown civilisation, when two intact pre-Columbian mummies, a child and an adult, were unearthed.

The skeletal remains of other women were also exhumed, probably the victims of sacrificial ceremonies to the gods. A small exhibition room and guided tour shed light on the secrets of this ancient culture.

Huaca Pucllana
Calle General Borgoño cuadra 8 S/n
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 617 7148

http://huacapucllanamiraflores.pe/

content.title: Country Club Lima Hotel: the elegant setting of a majestic hacienda

introduction.small: A bucolic universe of nature and calm, this five-star hotel is an impressive building on the edge of an 18-hole golf course.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Country Club Lima Hotel: the elegant setting of a majestic hacienda

paragraphs.text:
An architectural treasure, this imposing Spanish hacienda exudes an aristocratic atmosphere. Built in 1927, it is a listed national monument, and a favourite meeting point for golf lovers.

Decorated in ‘Spanish classic' style, the 83 rooms and suites, including the presidential suite, provide flawless elegance and comfort, with eiderdown feather pillows, luxurious carpets, period furnishings, and chandeliers. The spa is renowned for the quality of its services, which include anti-stress treatments, Swedish massage, and aromatherapy. If time permits, offer yourself a moment of sun and a swim in the beautiful pool, shaded by palm trees.

Before leaving the onslaught of tropical nights, stop off at the lobby bar, a stained-glass-lined beauty with the chic feel of an English club.

Country Club Lima Hotel
Calle Los Eucaliptos 590
San Isidro
Lima 27

+51 (0)1 611 9000

www.hotelcountry.com/es/

Rooms: from 732 PEN

content.title: Belmond Miraflores Park: the horizon in sight

introduction.small: Dressed in a glittering glass facade, this modern architectural jewel has stunning views of the Pacific.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Belmond Miraflores Park: the horizon in sight

paragraphs.text:
It's hard to beat this Peruvian flagship hotel, affiliated with the Orient Express chain. Ultra-luxurious, the monumental staircase and intimate library set the tone.

A few steps from Playa Redondo, its location makes it the ideal base camp from whence to explore the many architectural treasures in the city centre. The surrounding streets abound with shops, museums, and attractions. The rooms and suites are generous and bright, with windows opening onto flower gardens or the seafront. All the standard modern facilities of a luxury hotel of this category are in place. The spectacular infinity pool on the top floor provides a refreshing perspective after an active day in the bustling city.

Belmond Miraflores Park
Malecón de la Reserva 1035
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 610 4000

www.belmond.com/miraflores-park-lima

Rooms: from 982 PEN

content.title: The geoglyphs of Nazca: an unsolved mystery

introduction.small: Identified in 1939 by an American archaeologist who saw them while flying over the Pampa Colorada, the Nazca Lines remain an enigma.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The geoglyphs of Nazca: an unsolved mystery

paragraphs.text:
The only confirmed data about this site remains the date: it came into being around 900 BC. Nazca is one of the most obscure archaeological mysteries in the world. It has fascinated scientists for decades, including mathematician Maria Reiche, who has devoted a lifetime of research to discovering its secrets. The puzzle, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, remains the main tourist attraction of the small town of Nazca. Concentrated in a relatively small area, it is composed of 800 straight lines, 300 geometric figures, and more than 70 spectacular drawings of plants and animals, invisible from the ground. You have to fly over it to see its gigantic network of stylised forms. An alternative is to have someone drive you to the observation viewpoint on the Panamericana Sur, from where you can discern the perfection of the lizard, tree, and frog... But who, why, and how? These questions remain unanswered.

Nazca Site
Nazca
Peru

www.nascaperu.com

content.title: Rafael, a trendy brasserie for dinner with the Lima elite

introduction.small: Among the top 20 Peruvian restaurants, Rafael Osterling's establishment has the wind in its sails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rafael, a trendy brasserie for dinner with the Lima elite

paragraphs.text:
Between his cookbooks and his five restaurants in Peru and Colombia, Rafael Osterling reigns over an empire. His whole career is built on passion, talent, and the know-how forged by many professional experiences in Europe, notably in Paris as a chef at Le Cordon Bleu.

In Latin America, the Lima native has quickly made a name for himself thanks to an intuitive approach to Peruvian cuisine kindled by a few Mediterranean touches. His stronghold in Miraflores is a very fashionable brasserie, part Art Deco, part contemporary art. The menu highlights seafood and seasonal market choices.

Let yourself be tempted by the delicate flavours of grilled conches, prawn ravioli, roasted corn and mozzarella, and oven-cooked kid goat in milk, complemented by the fruity notes of Intipalka, a local white wine.

Restaurant Rafael
San Martín 300
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 242 4149

www.rafaelosterling.pe/es/lima.html

Dishes: from 93 PEN

content.title: Central: a Miraflores institution

introduction.small: A contemporary setting on a vast scale, for dinner overlooking a futuristic kitchen with the store room upstairs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Central: a Miraflores institution

paragraphs.text:
You are in the fiefdom of Virgilio Martínez Véliz, star of the new generation, many times rewarded for his innovations.

This chef will launch you on a vertiginous journey of perfection, inspired by terroir and fundamentals that he revisits with a light touch. Having worked with the biggest names in gastronomy in London, Bogota, Madrid, and New York, Martínez Véliz has built his own successful signature, which oscillates between fusion and Peruvian. The peak experience is his nine-course tasting menu, combining land and sea. A masterful exercise in style, it incorporates a careful study of food biodiversity.

On the menu of this restaurant, considered among the very best in Peru, are many unusual ingredients and pairings, such as cactus, sweet cucumber, and maca root. Try the loach, a freshwater fish with very tender meat, served with huarango and sweet potato leaves.

Central Restaurante
Santa Isabel 376
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 242 8515

www.centralrestaurante.com.pe

Menu: around 500 PEN

content.title: Monasterio de San Francisco: a priceless religious jewel

introduction.small: A huge 17th-century architectural complex, probably the most important in the New World, which miraculously resisted the 1687 earthquake.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Monasterio de San Francisco: a priceless religious jewel

paragraphs.text:
Dedicated to the Franciscan order, this monastery-church does not go unnoticed. The bright yellow facade, flanked by two massive towers of hewn stones, is a fine example of Spanish Baroque. Its interior reveals a choir flooded with lights, with Moorish-inspired white and red arches.

There is an admirable series of chapels and some very ornate altars. The outbuildings include a colonnaded cloister. There is also a secret garden and an outstanding library with original coffered ceilings. The monks had nearly 25,000 rare books at their disposal, some predating the Spanish conquest.

Among the many items of interest is the monumental Moorish dome in Panama cedar. It watches over the entrance to the monastery, and the corridors are covered with tiles from Seville. The underground floor, famous for its crypts and catacombs, attracts many visitors.

Monasterio de San Francisco
Jirón Lampa y Ancash
Cercado de Lima
Lima 15001

+51 (0)1 426 7377

www.museocatacumbas.com

content.title: The road to the beaches: sun and white sand

introduction.small: With 2,500 kilometres of Pacific coastline, Peru is a true paradise that celebrates surfing, beach, and sun.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The road to the beaches: sun and white sand

paragraphs.text: After discovering the countless treasures of Peru, it is time to kick back and relax. Take the road along the Pacific coast to Ancon, a small fisherman's cove with a modern spa resort. The sea here is perfect for swimming: the vast bay of El Silencio has clear, calm waters. Punta Rocas, a favourite surfing beach, hosts the national championships. The people of Lima like the festive atmosphere of Punta Hermosa. Its three small sandy coves and many terraces come alive on weekends. The great resort town of Bartolo stands out with a rocky shoreline, slapped with strong waves. Frequented by the gilded youth is the famous Avenue Asia, at kilometre 97 of the Panamericana Highway South, with its chic private beaches.

content.title: Larcomar: an outdoor shopping mall

introduction.small: Overlooking the Pacific Ocean, this universe dedicated to shopping is one of the prides of the Peruvian capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Larcomar: an outdoor shopping mall

paragraphs.text:
This ultra-modern shopping centre offers the best shopping and entertainment in Lima. With beautiful views of the Costa Verde, it is the idea place for a romantic afternoon, or for watching the sun set over the Pacific.

The cosmopolitan clientele is a mix of locals and visitors, including cruise-ship tourists. All the major international brands are represented, and there are plenty of nice terraces and a variety of restaurants serving all manner of cuisine. There's a multiplex cinema that screens international films, a theatre, bookstore, library, and several agencies specialising in trips and treks. Needless to say, this beautiful space, among the most attractive in the affluent Miraflores district, attracts huge crowds.

Larcomar
Avenida Malecon de la Reserva 610
Miraflores
Lima 15074

+51 (0)1 625 4343

www.larcomar.com
